comments.commentBody:
A few suggestions:
- eliminate the subsidy on less then first class mail
- reduce deliveries to two or three per week; nothing that is time sensitive is mailed
- reduce the number of post offices by at least two-thirds by consolidating facilities
- renegotiate the labor contracts
- eliminate Congressional review of operating decisions
there is something wrong with soccer , period. beautiful game, no doubt. but the only game in the world with this level of nationalistic thuggery.

Wow, Jeter has a huge day and the Yanks are suddenly up a game and a half in the AL East and the BATS section of the NY Times has.... this story. Really, is this supposed to get a lot of comments???

What happened to all those great BATS blogs a few weeks and months back when you were questioning whether Jeter was washed up and should basically retire, or slide down in the lineup, or commit hari kiri or something? And what about all the posting after the Yanks had lost a few series to Boston, about whether the Yanks were dead in the wind?

Where are all the BATS blogs now about the less than mighty Red Sox, after spending tens of millions of dollars in free agency, and are slumping toward the post season? How about the posting looking at the fact that with with something like 20 games to go, the Yankees, who didn't spend much at all in free agency in 2011 (granted, because Cliff Lee headed to Philadelphia, but credit the Yanks for not making much of a move at the trading deadline) now control their own destiny. This is a team that I didn't even think would make the playoffs.

O Coehlo, where are YOU for gawd's sake? Not BJ Wallace - where are YOU?

At Forest Hills in the 1970s (I can't remember if it was during the Open or the RFK charity tournament in mid-summer) I watched Bud play tennis barefoot on one of the club's Har Tru courts. He was famous (or infamous) for playing barefoot--though I assume he did not do so on hard courts!

Though I generally enjoyed his insights and knowledge of tennis history, he sometimes got out of hand. I remember him interviewing Tracy Austin at the US Open in either 1977 or 1978 when she had burst on the scene as a teenage. Collins thanked her, in paternal, if not downright patronizing tone, for all the excitement she had brought, then leaned in and kissed her on the cheek. I cringed, and it looked like Austin did too.

I watched some of the match online tonight since there was no T.C. Picture quality wasn't horrible, but it's not like watching it in H.D. on a big television. The worst part is losing DVR capability. Not easy to tell the family that we need to hurry up and get home so I can watch tennis.

Looking at other countries, mail in the US is one of the cheapest around, but as a sign of the times, we love to complain about everything to the government, while at the same time wanting everything.
America has become a country of whiners. We don't care anymore about the greater good, we only care about ourselves. We are very upset if the US post office raises it's rate by a few pennies and we get even more upset when the US mail they wants to give up Saturday delivery, how dare they?
We will be the first to run to the government to ask for assistant in case of disaster or simply a road or bridge not being maintained well, or m prescription drugs are too expensive, but we do NOT want to pay for anything, we don't even want to pay taxes. Americans don't seem to believe in democracy anymore, democracy meaning you get what you pay for.
It has become a country where self interest is number one and everyone else can go and ... themselves.
At the same time we keep saying we are the number one country in the world. Unfortunately these things don't go together very well. As a whole America is on a steep downward slope, which welcomes extremism from all sides.

They need to go Chapter 11, abbrogate their union contracts, end the stupid deals made when everyone thought that money fell out of the sky, close a ton of offices, actually expect their people to work, demand efficiency and then come back anew.
Either that or just close the place down and all of us will learn to deal. In reality I look forward to not getting all that junk mail anymore.
And really, someone walking around with a bag or driving a car with a bag putting small items in a box in the 21st century? Who else has such a stupid business model? Even railroads know how to use the internet.

As one who is eking out a small livelihood selling via eBay to say the effect of the USPS ceasing deliveries would be catastrophic is a huge understatement. I cannot afford to send my many parcels via UPS or FedEx, and would be driven out of business in the blink of an eye, as would millions of other sellers. The billions in lost revenues and the millions who would suddenly lose their at-home jobs, would have a huge effect on the economy. That is to say nothing of the huge effect it would have on eBay's revenues and stock value. I hope Congress can collectively agree that their general current tendency to hold up virtually everything, regardless of the effect on Americans, will be put aside to help an American institution, and save millions of Americans from certain economic disaster.

It was announced early in President Obama's term by the Republican leadership that they wanted his policies to fail. Some literally wanted him to fail.  It's always easier to tear things down than to build them up. Typically, it takes little time and even less talent to unleash  destructive forces. To create, build strong institutions, and do the work to set in motion positive change has always been our great challenge. It takes our whole society working together, unselfishly, to insure we have the best  future.

The health and well being of a country is generally reflected in the following:

Roads
Rail service
Bridges
Airports
Postal Service
Internet service
Public Restrooms
Other public services such as ability to navigate within the country, make a phone call etc. Note this has nothing to do with being on the dole.

Now, can anyone tell me US is anywhere in the top 10 in any of the above?

The health and wealth of the country is measured not by the size of the private mansions behind it's citizens compound walls. You can find those any third world country.

A good working postal system has pretty much marked the advent of civilization and organized society as we know it.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mail#Early_postal_systems

This is not some nostalgic ranting as there are still vital pieces of paper that flow back and forth which cannot be moved over to electronic form. Yes some of those stuff that go in the postal system are dispensable/replaceable. So what? This is like saying most of what can be gained in a marriage can be gained by being room-mates and volunteering for an orphanage!

I can understand not having enough money to spend a spaceship to the Mars. But not having the wherewithal to organize a mail delivery from Peoria to Topeka is truly mind boggling.

This is just a way station on the way to stone age society.

You can can complain all you want about big government and deficits.. but if you fail to see some thing as obvious as this I doubt anything can change your mind at this time.

Post office has been mismanaged for too long.  File for reorganization.  Better yet it should be privatized and run to make a profit.  It can be done.  We need the imput of the people, not government.

Adapt, innovate, or get out of the way. That's how it's done in the private sector and that's why it works better than anything a government with no personal investment or accountability will ever do.

What about sponsored mail? Say a letter is mailed across the country and it gets sponsored by a big business like Coca cola, which pays an additional ten cent stamp to plaster its logo on the letter next to the stamp.  The letter gets to the recipient, Coke gets targeted advertising, USPS gets more revenue.  Maybe allow the sender to get a revenue share to make it work well all around?

There's no need to get into the angry politics of this. The fact we're even discussing this possibility represents how we voters and citizens have chosen to run an American institution into the ground, mainly for the promise of the immediate justification and flashy capitalist modeling of FedEx and UPS.

I'm 39 years old. I've seen enough changes in my country to this point to be saddened, nostalgic and severely pained the day we ultimately do close down that last post office.

Sometimes, progress really isn't so pretty.

The U.S. Federal government bars Fed Ex, USPS, and others from setting rates even close to lower than USPS prices in order to allow the bloated government-run USPS to compete. The USPS also operates unnecessary offices (e.g., 2 offices in tiny Freeport, Maine and 2 offices and tiny Old Town, Maine) both towns of only seven thousand residents. If my Senator wasn't acting stupidly all the time she ought to know this.

That still said, I agree that we should still try save the USPS because of the niche services it provides. But maybe the USPS Union should try to trim its expenses. It had hundreds of years to purchase its buildings and infrastructure--YET it still rents them! Look it up! What a cozy arrangement for certain individuals that must be?!?

As ineffective as the Democrats are often, the Republican propaganda machine financed by Rupert and the Kochs has killed that party as far as I'm concerned. They know one thing only -- fanatic loyalty to their big-money contributors. Despite their rhetoric otherwise, they care nothing about the average Joe and Jane, and are in the process of driving this country into the ground.

Is there any way to discuss the state of the post office without reverting to the rhetoric of disaster and crisis? The situation of the USPS is years in the making, and as many savvy commenters have made clear, the "crunch" they are feeling has been exacerbated by counter-productive legislation in 2006 in regards to paying back debt. Is there not any vestige of a functioning welfare state that won't be eviscerated, both financially, but pre-emptively as well in the way the conversation is framed by politicians and the media. This narrative of all types of orgs finally getting their come-uppance in terms of their outstanding debt is presented as if it fell from the sky in most cases.

Someone else said it: the USPS is a SERVICE, not a for-profit company. Despite its struggles, I am simply amazed at its efficiency, reliability and affordability. And that I know my mail man. This is not me hanging onto nostalgia for snail mail; if anything, its nostalgia for a service held in common, in the interest of the public and which, being labor intensive compensates labor fairly (or used to...). Now we have yet another story framed by how "expensive" labor is blah blah. If we are not going to spend money so that people have stable, well-paying jobs, what else do we want to do with it as a society? Long live the USPS.

Why should the US Post Office be expected to make a profit as a business would? The fire fighters, police, road builders etc. in your community are paid from taxes because they provide a service which we collectively agree is worth having. Though I do almost everything online, I personally am grateful for the ability to send and receive letters at an affordable cost and think it's in the interest of a civilized nation to extend that service to everyone (though I agree with the suggestion that companies sending unsolicited mail should pay much more to do so).

That being said, I do wonder if the postal service would provide more value at cheaper cost if it were modernized a bit. Suggestions:

1. allow people to send physical letters by email (eliminates part of the cost of sending letters);
2. allow the reverse, by implementing a nationwide, uniform scanning service based on what several private companies do for certain small areas, where you can opt to shred, receive digitally, or receive original paper copies of individual articles. Though possibly not purely profitable on a nationwide scale, this could substantially reduce costs since many articles of mail could be delivered electronically or shredded without the cost of physical delivery;
3. provide infrastructure for directly depositing checks into bank accounts (relies on infrastructure in (2))
4. implement optional, permanent, simplified universal mail addresses which would identify recipients without placing physical addresses on letters (simpler, less error prone and more secure).

A nation that can communicate through a wide variety of ways is a stronger one. Regardless of what innovation the USPS can, should, or eventually does adopt, I hope Congress gets a clue on this one (though I doubt they will). While I use UPS and FEDEX as the need arises, I think we all lose out if all the basic infrastructure in this country gets jobbed out to corporations. Worked great on Wall St., didn't it?
I dunno.  Typical Mike T but Too much shuffling on the o-line for my taste. Brunnell hasn't thrown pass since last year and we still haven't found an edge rusher.
What right does Comcast have to complain about nothing when they continually withhold their Sportsnet Philly channel from Directv?

Tennis Channel should be a la carte, available on a sports tier for those who want to pay for it. No big loss. Between ESPN, CBS, and streaming video there's enough to go around. It's very niche, like the sports channels in Spanish or alternate college sports channels.

Well, I just called Verizon and had them remove my sports tier, because I was paying $9.99 a month solely to get Tennis Channel, and that's $9.99 a month I don't need to spend.  We'll see how long I go before calling an alternate cable provider...

I don't understand how business has slowed down for the Post Office, especially with businesses like eBay which generate lots of mail because of thousands of transactions a day are taking place. Once I started selling on eBay I sent packages out almost daily, whereas before that, maybe bi-monthly for birthdays  etc. I have no problem with the Post office, but now wonder if we'll be hearing the same sad tidings about our new Government Run Healthcare System in a couple of years...This has given me something to think about, especially if that system becomes the only source of healthcare we get....

Let it close until further notice. We'll get by ... somehow.

With the exception of several very friendly mail carriers and a few (ONLY a few) counter clerks among the dozens I have dealt with, I have never seen an organization determined to blatantly insult and abuse its customers.

I say this from experience, having worked in the mail-order retail business for some years, and using the USPS primarily when shipping overseas (I will admit FedEx and UPS and DHL are not nearly as competitive in the International package-delivery market). I have had occasion to witness a deliberate type of inefficiency and in-your-face red-tape bureaucracy.

Once I complained to the Postmaster General in my city, regarding horribly bad customer service that crossed the line into malice and Barney Fife high-handedness, and the PM basically told me to get lost.

Shut it down, and good riddance.

After all is said done the Postal Service dilemma is a catch 22. And, like everyone else who has been permanently laid off the postal workers could be next in line. There doesn't seem to be a light at the end of Congress's tunnel vision. Rest assure that the tea bagging Republicans won't be there to help either: nor, will President Obama. This economic disaster only seems to be getting worse by the minute. I suspect that we are seeing the end of America, as we knew it.
